data.question: What is the title of the article?
data.answer: Assembly of a Three-Dimensional Polyknotted Coordination Polymer

data.question: Who is the corresponding author for the article?
What is the publication date of the article?
What type of structure does the coordination polymer {[Cd2(4,4‘-pytz)3(μ-NO3)(NO3)3(MeOH)]}∞, 1, display?
How are the Cd(II) centers in the polymer described in the article connected?
data.answer: Each Cd(II) center is coordinated by three pyridyl N-donors arranged in an approximate T-shaped geometry to form a ladder motif.

data.question: What role does the MeOH solvent play in determining the structure of the polymer mentioned in the article?
data.answer: The MeOH solvent is influential in determining the structure of the polymer.

data.question: What phenomenon is exhibited by the coordination polymer described in the article?
Is the coordination polymer described in the article a polyrotaxane?
data.answer: No, it is not a polyrotaxane because each ladder is not independent of the other interpenetrating ladders due to the linking NO3- bridges joining them together.

data.question: What is the difference between the complexes 1 and 3 mentioned in the article?
data.answer: In complex 1, the ladders are connected through bridging NO3- anions, while in complex 3, the ladders are independent of each other and not connected through bridging NO3- anions.

data.question: What happens when EtOH is used instead of MeOH in the synthesis of the polymer?
data.answer: A simpler, noninterpenetrated, molecular ladder motif 2 is observed.

data.question: How are the ladders in the coordination polymer interconnected?
data.answer: The ladders are interconnected perpendicularly by two other ladders.

data.question: What is the significance of the bridging NO3- anion in the structure of the coordination polymer?
data.answer: The bridging NO3- anion links the Cd(II) centers at the intersections of one ladder to a Cd(II) center located at the corner of a square section of one of the perpendicularly interpenetrated ladders, linking all the ladders together.

data.question: Is the coordination polymer described in the article the first example of its type of knotting in coordination polymers?
Does the coordination polymer described in the article exhibit polyrotaxanation?
Are the individual ladders in the coordination polymer independent of each other?
Is the coordination polymer described in the article a discrete molecular structure?
Does the coordination polymer form a three-dimensional polymeric network?
Is the coordination polymer described in the article constructed of multiple molecules?
Does the coordination polymer described in the article form a fused polyknotted array?
Is the phenomenon of polycatenation unique to the coordination polymer described in the article?
